Articles.Content: Well, I\'ve been trying to find an IRC client that wasn\'t from windows 98. Anybody have any IRC clients?

Most people I know use MiRC or HydraIRC. Both seem alright.

I use irssi, personally, which uses a command line interface although it\'s not 'from windows 98.'

I use Xchat, although that\'s mainly because it works on both my gaming machine and the Linux box I use when I\'m away from home.

There\'s not much innovation you can do with IRC, so there\'s really no reason to insist on a client that was started recently over one that\'s been around (and stable) since, say, 98.
I use IceChat. It\'s pretty easy to set-up once you get the hang of it. Just be sure to look through the guide once or twice
I use Pidgin, because it lets me connect to all of my IM accounts (gmail, yahoo, facebook, IRC, lots more that I don\'t use) through one client.

I use Pidgin, because it lets me connect to all of my IM accounts (gmail, yahoo, facebook, IRC, lots more that I don\'t use) through one client.

I used to use pidgin on a tablet that I got working from 08.(My sisters friend had the tablet but couldn\'t get it working so she gave it to her, and then my sister gave it to me.) Didn\'t know it had a windows version.
I use Chatzilla... which is a Firefox plugin. Never had any issues with it.
X-Chat WDK, although I have a license for mIRC somewhere, too. X-Chat WDK is generally more stable than mIRC and is scriptable by Lua, Python, and Perl, though, so I tend to use it more often.

I use xchat. Easy setup, scriptable (if you have the time/effort to give) and works/looks nice on my ubuntu laptop.

I didn\'t really care for mIRC, the cost and just the layout overall

I used ChatZilla back when my desktops weren\'t RAM-limited. It\'s rather nice if you already use Firefox, and doesn\'t have the learning curve of a CLI client.

These days, I stick with irssi. I know a bit more about IRC, and see the above comment on RAM limitations.

On my phone (a Droid 3), I use AndChat.
